name: helium purification | helium | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/4653/documentation

This datasets represents purification of helium, crude to helium Grade - A and its liquefaction. The technology used for helium purification is pressure swing adsorption (PSA) and liquefaction unit. The dataset is based on literature and estimates. The uncertainty of the data is rather high.;The activity is mass unbalanced due to missing "used charcoal" exchange. 

This activity boundaries are given by the boundaries of the technology - the PSA (pressure swing adsorbtion) and liquefaction unit. The activity starts when helium, crude enters this technology.

This activity ends when purified, liquified Grade - A helium (99.995% of helium) leaves the technology.
category: C:Manufacturing/20:Manufacture of chemicals and chemical products/201:Manufacture of basic chemicals, fertilizers and nitrogen compounds, plastics/2011:Manufacture of basic chemicals

processDocumentation.geographyDescription: The inventory is modelled for the world..
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: The technology used for helium purification is pressure swing adsorption (PSA).;Scheme of Pressure-Swing Adsorbtion - PSA - (Ullmann's Encyclopedia)
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription: Transports are calculated with standard values.

exchanges.description:
Calculated based on literature and assumptions.

1.81E+08m3 is the global production of Grade-A helium in the world in 2005 (USGS, http://minerals.usgs.gov/minerals/pubs/commodity/helium/heliumyb05.pdf, accessed 20130403)

0.165 kg/m3 is density of helium

99.995% is the fraction of helium in Grade-A helium

90% is the efficiency of helium purification (i.e. 10% are losses), estimate

flow.name: helium
flow.category: C:Manufacturing/20:Manufacture of chemicals and chemical products/201:Manufacture of basic chemicals, fertilizers and nitrogen compounds, plastics/2011:Manufacture of basic chemicals

exchanges.description:
Calculated value.

10% of helium is lost during this process (estimate)

0.75 is the fraction of helium in helium, crude

Calculated value based on estimates.

Based on adsorbent/adsorbed inpurities chart, for the example of a helium - carbon monoxide mixture, how carbon monoxide, which is easily adsorbed, reaches the equilibrium loading, a , on the molecular sieve, while pure helium exits the adsorber. When the adsorber capacity is exhausted, the adsorbent must be regenerated. 

Charcoal is considered to be adequate representative of the adsorber used in the PSA unit. The amount of adsorber needed per kg of helium purified is calculated to be 0.032 kg of adsorber/ 1 kg of inpurities filtered out. Since the helium, crude consist from 75% of helium the remaining 25% are the inpurities which need to be adsorbed.

Ideally an "used charcoal" exchange should be created together with it's treatment "treatment of used charcoal". Since there are no data available this exchange is omitted, causing the activity to be unbalanced.

exchanges.description:
Calculated based on literature values and estimates.

Liquid nitrogen is used during helium purification for washing the final product. It can be recycled several times. The final make-up amount of liquid nitrogen needed per kg of final product is estimated to be 5ppm (Helium Purification, Wright, M., The Jefferson National Accelerator Facility, presentation from 20110419, https://www.jlab.org/conferences/cryo/JLAB%20Helium%20Purification.pdf, accessed 20130405).

exchanges.description:
Calculated based on producer's data and estimates.

The electricity consumption of the pure liquified helium production is between 7 - 18 kWh/kg of liquified helium, Grade - A (Linde, http://www.linde-kryotechnik.ch/public/fachberichte/cec2007_fro.pdf, accessed 20130405). The PSA (pressure swing adsorbsion) technology which represents the purification of helium and the liquefaction unit are only one part of the whole chain. It is estimated that these two technologies represents 20% of the total electricity consumption.

In general the costs for electricity cover approximatelly 1/3 of all the costs of helium purification.
